In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. S. sells fruits, earning an income of USD 5 per day. S. is married and resides with her husband and a child in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, the most populated city in the country. The family has to spend USD 70 on food, USD 10 on electricity, and USD 20 on other necessary expenses every month. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike and more fruits to resell.

location.town: Mean Chey District, Phnom Penh City

loans.name: Enhzaya

texts.en: Enhzaya G. is 30 years old and lives with her husband and two-year-old child in Zavhan Province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in their own house and fenced area. Her daughter is in a local kindergarten and her husband helps her with the business. Enhzaya operates a used clothing retail business in her town. She started her business in 2000 selling a variety of secondhand products in Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia. She moved to her current town in 2010 and continued to operate her used product trading business. After many years of successful operation, she has gained a lot of experience as a businesswoman. Enhzaya is a hardworking and honest woman who fights to build a decent life for her family. She is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more used goods in order to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To purchase more used goods for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a motorbike.

By doing so, her child will be able to start a business as a tuk-tuk (auto rickshaw) driver. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. S. sells groceries, earning an income of $7 US per day. S. is married and resides with her husband and two children in Phnom Penh, the most populated city in Cambodia. The family spends $73 US on food, $5 US on electricity, and $50 US on other necessary expenses every month. This is S.'s first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike with a trailer attached for her child to start a business

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Sam S. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase more fabrics to expand her business. By doing so, she will be able to generate a better income. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.

S. is a tailor, earning an income of $3 per day. S. is married and resides with her husband and two children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known for being the most populated city in the country. The family has to spend $80 on food, $15 on electricity supply, and $15 on other necessary expenses every month. 

This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more fabrics to expand the current business

loans.name: Annalyn

texts.en:
Annalyn L. is from the village of Brgy. Quirino, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 32 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Annalyn owns and operates a motorcycle transport business. She has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Annalyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Annalyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase tires and other accessories. Annalyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Annalyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair a vehicle

Wilbert is requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be his first loan from ASKI. texts.en:
Lorna B. is from the village of Villaluz, Benito Soliven, Isabela. She is 29 years old. Lorna is the group leader of an 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Lorna B..

Lorna is married and has 1 infant. She owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Lorna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Lorna from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

texts.en: Dalia is a 32-year-old single woman from Bint Jbeil. She has been the owner of a religious dress shop since 2008 with 15 years of experience in this field. Dalia is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the first time in order to expand her business with new dress collections. Dalia’s quality of products is highly recommended by her clients, as she claims she sells the most requested type of cloth. She hopes to expand more and more until she opens her own factory and produces her own designs.

loans.use: To buy new collections

loans.name: Samira

texts.en: Samira is a 58-year-old married woman from Bint Jbeil who has worked as a tailor since 1995. She is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to increase her products and capital. Samira works hard for her family and their needs; all her work is just for them as she struggles to expand her business. She dreams of building a house for each one of her children and that’s her aim for the future. Her neighbors like her a lot and recommend working with her. She is well experienced and honest.

loans.use: to buy new products and tools

loans.name: Lina

texts.en: Lina is a 31-year-old married woman, the mother of three children and owner of a grocery store since 2000. Lina is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to increase her goods and add new items to her shop. This is an important source of livelihood for Lina’s family since she supports her husband in their social and financial lives. Lina works hard at customer service because she believes clients are her treasure to handle more in the future. She hopes to expand her business and improve its decor.

loans.use: to increase her stock

loans.name: Pum

texts.en:
Pum S., 36, is a farmer, earning $2.60 US per day. S. is married and lives with her husband and four children in Takeo province, Cambodia – an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. Her husband is a teacher, earning $2 US per day. The family has to spend $50 US on food, $5 US on electricity and $70 US on other expenses every month.

S. is requesting a loan of $500 US to purchase a new motorbike for her husband to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair their house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S. appears in the photograph with her family.

loans.name: Herminio

Herminio C. Jr. is from the village of Dist. 4. He is 45 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Herminio has been engaged in his business for over 18 years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP per harvest.

He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

Alginbert L. is from the village of Dist.4, Sa Manuel, Isabela. He is 24 years old, married and has 1 school-aged child. Alginbert owns and operates a farming business, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. Alginbert has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 35,000 PHP every harvest season.

In 2010, Alginbert joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alginbert is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Alginbert from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: San

texts.en: San S., 31, sells desserts, earning an income of 3 USD per day. S. is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. Her husband is a construction foreman, earning an income of 5 USD per day. The family spends 18 USD on food, 10 USD on electricity and 30 USD on other necessary expenses every month. S. is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to purchase more rice to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy rice to resell

The family has to spend $18 US on food, $10 US on electricity and $30 US on other expenses every month. S. is requesting a loan of $900 US to purchase vegetables to resell. T. is married and resides with her husband and five children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of 5 USD per day. The family spends 11 USD on food, 10 USD on electricity and 20 USD on other necessary expenses every month. T. is requesting a loan of 800 USD to purchase a motorbike for the family's use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. loans.name: Estelita's Group

texts.en:
Estelita C. is from the village of San Andes. She is 48 years old. Estelita is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Estelita C. group.

Estelita is married and has 1 adult-aged child. She owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Estelita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2005, Estelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Estelita is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 11th loan taken out by Estelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en:
Annabelle D. is from the village of Brgy. Quirino, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 37 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Annabelle owns  and operates a butcher shop, butchering and selling pork and chicken meat in the market. Annabelle has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Annabelle joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Annabelle has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Annabelle is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Annabelle from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Sean

texts.en:
Sean O., 41, is a farmer, earning an income of $3 per day. O. is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. 

The family has to spend $11 on food, $10 on electricity supply, and $20 on other necessary expenses every month. 

O. is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase fertilizer and rice seeds to improve her farming business. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  

This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and rice seeds to improve the farming business

loans.name: Chet

texts.en:
Chet S., 27, is a farmer, earning an income of $2 per day. S. is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. Her husband is a soldier, earning an income of $3 per day. 

The family has to spend $11 on food, $10 on electricity supply and $20 on other necessary expenses every month. 

S. is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase a motorbike for the family to use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  

This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S. appears in the photograph with her family.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for family use

loans.name: Chourng

texts.en:
Chourng N., 33, grows and sells vegetables, earning an income of $3 per day. N. is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of $3 per day. 

The family has to spend $11 on food, $10 on electricity supply and $20 on other necessary expenses every month. 

N. is requesting a loan of $900 to purchase more vegetables to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  

This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to resell

loans.name: Noun

texts.en:
Noun T., 59, is married with two children living at home in the Takeo province. She is a farmer, typically making $1 each day, and her husband runs a moto-taxi. Her family is also supported by her husband’s $2 income each day, along with the income of two children, one who works in a grocery store and another who is a blacksmith. 

Noun T. is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase more blacksmith tools for her son. Noun T. is pictured with her husband at home.

loans.use: To purchase blacksmith tools

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok P., 47, is a farmer, earning $1 US per day. P. is married and lives with her husband and four children in Takeo province, Cambodia – an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. Her husband sells hammocks, earning $5 US per day. The family has to spend $25 US on food, $10 US on electricity and $25 US on other expenses every month. P. is requesting a loan of $400 US to purchase a motorbike for her child to start a business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her child to start a new business

loans.name: Yem

texts.en:
Yem S., 49, is a farmer, earning an income of $2 per day. S. is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. 

The family has to spend $20 on food, $10 on electricity supply and $60 on other necessary expenses every month. 

S. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for the family to use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  

This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for family use

loans.name: But

texts.en:
But H., 36, is married with three children living at home in Takeo province. She works in a grocery store, typically making US $3 each day and her husband works collecting palm juice. Her family is also supported by her husband’s US $2 income each day along with the income of one child who works in construction. But H. is asking for a loan of US $600 to purchase a motorbike for her husband. This motorbike will be used to transport palm juice to sell at the market. Moreover, But H. will use this motorbike to transport groceries from the market to sell at home. 

But H. is pictured with her husband and her youngest son.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo Y., 50, sells food and groceries, earning $10 US per day. Y. is married and lives with her husband and three children in Takeo province, Cambodia – an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. Her husband is a farmer, earning $2 US per day. The family has to spend $30 US on food, $5 US on electricity and $50 US on other expenses every month. Y. is requesting a loan of $400 US to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Am

texts.en:
Am S. A., 35, has a business running a moto-taxi in the Takeo province. He has been operating this business since 2008 and is able to make about $5 of profit each day. His wife sells groceries at home, typically making $2 per day. 

This couple has five young children; two are in school and three are too young to attend. 

To earn more, Am S. A. will purchase rice and take off the husk with the intention of reselling the rice and turning a profit. He is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase his income and raise his family’s standard of living. 

Am S. A. is pictured with his wife and his youngest daughter at home.

loans.use: To purchase rice to resell

loans.name: Ty

texts.en: Ty P., 45, is a widow and lives with three children in Takeo province. Since 2007, she has been selling porridge and is able to make about US$2 of profit each day, along with the income of two children who work in construction. Ty P. will purchase rice and take off the husk with the intention of reselling the rice and turning over a profit. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a way to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To sell rice

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea S. A., 48, is a construction foreman living in Takeo province with his wife and three children. Doing construction work, he is able to make about $5 US each day, while his wife works growing rice and vegetables. On average, she makes $1 US per day. This couple is also supported by one child who works in construction like the father. 

Chea S. A. is asking for a loan of $600 US to purchase a small tractor to plow the farmland and also to rent to other farmers who have no cow or small tractor to plow their land.

loans.use: To purchase a small tractor

loans.name: Bermet

texts.en:
Bermet O. is a 53-year-old farmer with four children. Her family has been engaged in cattle breeding for the past 20 years, which is the means of subsistence for them. Bermet started this activity with initial capital of only 4,000 soms (KGS) and worked hard to achieve success. Due to her persistent and hardworking personality, Bermet managed to buy a truck which is now used for transportation. Today, she has two milk cows and one bull calf and plans to enlarge the number of her cattle. 

For this very reason, Bermet has applied for a loan of 120,000 KGS to broaden her business by purchasing two milk cows and two bull calves. With the revenue from this investment, she plans to broaden her business. All members of Bermet’s united family are doing their best to make the future prosperous and stable.

======================================

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target an especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Mrs. Chin Kano Village Bank Group

texts.en:
In Pong Tuek village, Takeo province, live 17 people who make up a village-bank loan. Mrs. Chin K. is the village bank president. She has been selected by the other members, who will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their families' living conditions. 

She is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land in which to grow rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Yen Im, is a farming-supplies producer who can earn some money to support his family. Although they try to work hard, they earn little money. So to improve their family's living, Mrs. Chin K. is requesting a loan to buy some piglets for breeding to start a new business. 

She is a mother of two children who are both too young to work or study. 

All the members are shown in the picture but one of them is blocked.

loans.use: To buy some piglets

loans.name: Loem

texts.en:
Mrs. Loem N. was born in 1959 and is a villager in Thlok Doun Tum village in Takeo province. She is a widow with two children; one is a laborer at Malaya, the other is attending public school. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow rice to sell to support her family. 

She earns little income though she tries to work hard. So Mrs. Loem N. is asking for a loan to add to her savings--she will start a new business by buying a cow for breeding. With the rest of the loan she is going to hire farming laborers to harvest rice.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Kim Orn

texts.en: Mrs. Kim Orn Y. is living in Krang Chamraeun village in Takeo province. She was born in 1976. Nowadays, she and her husband, Mr. Huy Kuon, are farmers. They own a small piece of land where they can grow rice to sell to support their family. She is also a weaver. Since her business is going well from time to time, she wants to expand. So, for this purpose, Mrs. Kim Orn Y. is seeking a loan to buy more silk. She is the mother of two children who are attending public school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy more silk

loans.name: Phoeurk

texts.en: Mr. Phoeurk N. is a villager in Kdei Ta Hok village in Takeo province. He was born in 1975. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to grow rice to sell to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Yoem Kung, sells fruit in the local market and is able to earn some money to support the family. Mr. Phoeurk N. has some problems with the plantation because his field has infertile soil and it is far away from an irrigation system. So, to improve production, Mr. Phoeurk N. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline and pesticide. He is the father of three children: two of whom are studying in the local public school while the other is too young to work or study. His wife is in the picture with him.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gasoline and pesticide

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en: Francisco S. is a 55-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: buying and selling pigs and farming corn and vegetables. She lives in 112, Brgy. Dancalan, Ilog, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her livestock and farming businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Francisco is now borrowing PHP 12,000 so that she can continue to fund the operation of her pig business. This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 9,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Francisco aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable) way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: Fund the operations of her livestock business

loans.name: Charique

texts.en: Charique D. R. is from the village of Lawis. She is 29 years old. Charique is an individual member of PMPC. Charique is married and has five children. To make a living, Charique operates a beauty salon and is the beautician. Charique has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 12,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. In 2010, Charique joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Charique is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the first loan taken out by Charique from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy materials needed for her beauty salon
